tasks.task: Participant attends and engages in a Field to Fork webinar on growing garlic and other alliums.
subtasks: Watch the webinar introduction and acknowledge the presenter.
Take note of the webinar's purpose and schedules for future sessions.
Participate in the virtual environment by typing city and state in the chat box.
Respond to the sponsor's acknowledgment of USDA and North Dakota Department of Agriculture funding.
Voluntarily complete the post-webinar online survey for a chance to win prizes.
Listen to the speaker's introduction and qualifications.
Note the focus on garlic, onions, and leeks as the main allium crops discussed in North Dakota.
Understand the significance of cultural adaptability for alliums in a northern climate.
Learn about soil requirements, pH levels, and essential nutrient applications (N-P-K) for alliums.
Review irrigation practices, including the benefits of drip irrigation for alliums.
Identify the three types of garlic (elephant, softneck, hardneck) and the preferred type for North Dakota.
Follow the planting timeline for garlic (6-8 weeks before ground freezes) and proper spacing and depth.
Remember how to remove garlic scapes to direct growth to bulb development and use or sale of scapes.
Understand the harvesting criteria (60% leaf discoloration) and post-harvest curing process for garlic.
Note the storage requirements for garlic seed clove preservation.
Familiarize with onion types, including sets vs. seed, requirements for early season vigor, late-season maturing varieties, and storage organ responses to photoperiod.
Learn about onion cultivar preferences and the evaluation methods used in research trials.
Understand the differences between long-day, intermediate-day, and short-day onion types and their geographic planting suitability.
Consider the use of mulch for winter protection and weed suppression in garlic cultivation.
Recall leek cultivation steps, including starting from seed, acclimatization, and seasonal planting considerations.
Note the importance of proper soil coverage techniques for leek whiteness and edible part formation.
Take note of additional allium species mentioned (Chinese garlic, ornamental onions) and their ornamental uses.

tasks.task: To attend and engage in a Field to Fork webinar on growing garlic and other alliums in North Dakota (MAINTASK), participants must:
subtasks: - Watch the webinar introduction (SUBTASK).
- Acknowledge the presenter (SUBTASK).
- Take note of webinar purposes and future sessions (SUBTASK).
- Participate in virtual environment by joining chat (SUBTASK).
- Respond to sponsor acknowledgments (SUBTASK).
- Volunteer to complete survey for prizes (SUBTASK).
- Listen to the speaker's introduction and credentials (SUBTASK).
- Note focus on garlic, onions, and leeks (SUBTASK).
well-drained, sandy clay loam with pH 6-6.8 (SUBTASK).
6-8 weeks before ground freeze, around 12-36 inches row spacing, 3-4 inches depth (SUBTASK).
70-125 lbs N, 150 lbs P, 100 lbs K split over time (SUBTASK).
drip irrigation preferred due to reduced disease risk (SUBTASK).
- Remove scapes (flower stems) to direct nutrition to bulb (SUBTASK).
- Harvest at 60% leaf brown (SUBTASK), then cure indoors for 1-2 weeks (SUBTASK).
- Purchase sets (vigor higher) or seed; spacing and early growth (SUBTASK).
similar to other alliums (SUBTASK).
- Use mulch for winter protection and weed control (SUBTASK).
- Trim scapes in onions (SUBTASK).
- Start from seed in early spring, transplanted at 10-15 weeks (SUBTASK).
- Acclimatize transplants to outdoor conditions (SUBTASK).
- Grow in furrows, covering soil to blanch stems (SUBTASK).
- Mulch and weed control important for all alliums (SUBTASK).
- Various cultivar trials indicate German white might be best for North Dakota (SUBTASK).
long-day (good for ND) and photoperiod sensitivity (SUBTASK).
